choices.B: It can be used to perform database recovery when the database is opened
choices.A: It is available only when the database is open

discussion.content:
AE is correct because 
C is false - Each host requires a unique port number for Database Express configurations to avoid conflicts and ensure proper communication. So, statement C is not true.

What means:

host1 - EM Express1 - 5500

host3 - EM Express3 - 5500

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about Enterprise Manager Database Express? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
What does it mean by IMMEDIATE tho?

IMMEDIATE means the check will be done as soon as you make change in your session.
But DEFERRED means the check will be done only when you do commit.

Selected Answer: AD
A, D - true

SQL> SELECT constraint_name,constraint_type,table_name,status,deferred FROM user_constraints WHERE table_name='EMP';

CONSTRAINT_NAME CONSTRAINT_TYPE TABLE_NAME STATUS DEFERRED
--------------- --------------- ---------- -------- ---------
EMP_EMP_NO_PK P EMP ENABLED IMMEDIATE
EMP_MGR_FK R EMP DISABLED IMMEDIATE

choices.A: The primary key constraint will be enabled and IMMEDIATE.
choices.D: The foreign key constraint will be disabled.
choices.C: The foreign key constraint will be enabled and DEFERRED.
choices.B: The primary key constraint will be enabled and DEFERRED.
choices.E: The foreign key constraint will be enabled and IMMEDIATE.

discussion.content:
C, D is correct
NULL values are considered in the sort operation; by default, they are treated as the lowest values in an ascending sort and as the highest values in a descending sort.

Selected Answer: DE
A – false; following queries are executed correctly:
SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY 1;
SELECT emp_name, dept_id FROM employees ORDER BY emp_id;
B – false; no mention in Oracle documentation about numeric values order
C – false; Quoting Oracle documentation - options NULLS FIRST | NULLS LAST Specify whether returned rows containing null values should appear first or last in the ordering sequence. NULLS LAST is the default for ascending order, and NULLS FIRST is the default for descending order.
D – true; example: SELECT emp_name AS en, dept_id FROM employees ORDER BY en;
E – true; example:
SQL> SELECT emp_id,emp_name FROM employees WHERE UPPER(emp_name)='JONES' ORDER BY emp_name ASC;
 EMP_ID EMP_NAME
---------- ----------
 1 JONES
 7 JONES
 10 JOnes
 9 Jones

choices.F: Use the define command before executing the query.
choices.B: Execute the SET verify off command before executing the query.
choices.C: Use the undefine command before executing the query.
choices.D: Execute the SET VERIFY ON command before executing the query.
choices.A: Store the query in a script and pass the substitution value to the script when executing it.

choices.E: All constraints defined on HR.EMPLOYEES are dropped.
choices.D: Sequences used to populate columns in the HR.EMPLOYEES table are dropped.
choices.A: All indexes defined on HR.EMPLOYEES are dropped
choices.C: The HR.EMPLOYEES table may be moved to the recycle bin.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
Correct answer should be ACE

Reason for option C being correct:
C. The HR.EMPLOYEES table may be moved to the recycle bin: In Oracle 10g and later versions, when a DROP TABLE statement is executed, the table may not be immediately deleted but instead moved to the recycle bin. This allows for the possibility of restoring the table from the recycle bin if it was dropped by mistake. However, if the recycle bin is disabled or the PURGE clause is used, the table is completely deleted.

comments.content: D. Sequences used to populate columns in the HR.EMPLOYEES table are not dropped. Sequences are independent objects from tables, and dropping a table does not delete the associated sequences.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
Correct answers:

A. All indexes defined on HR.EMPLOYEES are dropped
C. The HR.EMPLOYEES table may be moved to the recycle bin.
E. All constraints defined on HR.EMPLOYEES are dropped.
